section_id: ## 4. Analysis and Properties of the Mean-Field Equations

hints.label: assumption-regularity-summary
hints.title: Summary of Regularity Assumptions
hints.content:
761: The well-posedness of the coupled mean-field system relies on the following assumptions, which are satisfied by the Canonical Euclidean Gas:
 762: *   **(H1)** The domains $X_{\text{valid}}$ and $V_{\text{alg}}$ are bounded and have smooth ($C^2$) boundaries.
 763: *   **(H2)** The reward potential $R_{\text{pos}}$ is $C^2$, making the force field $F$ globally Lipschitz.
 764: *   **(H3)** The flow field $u$ is $C^1$, and all physical parameters ($m, \gamma_{\text{fric}}, \Theta, \sigma_x$) are finite and positive.
 765: *   **(H4)** All algorithmic functions (e.g., the rescale function, companion selection) are measurable and satisfy the continuity properties established in the abstract framework.
 766: *   **(H5)** The killing rate function $c(z)$ is smooth ($C^\infty$), non-negative, and has compact support in a neighborhood of $\partial X_{\text{valid}}$.
 767: *   **(H6)** The revival rate $\lambda_{\text{revive}} > 0$ is a free positive constant independent of the timestep $\tau$ (typical values: 0.1-5).

hints.label: assumption-domain-regularity
hints.title: Regularity of the Valid Domain
hints.content:
803: The valid position domain $X_{\text{valid}} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ satisfies:
 804: 
 805: 1. **Smoothness**: $X_{\text{valid}}$ is an open, bounded domain with $C^3$ boundary $\partial X_{\text{valid}}$.
 806: 2. **Distance Function**: The signed distance function $d(x) := \text{dist}(x, \partial X_{\text{valid}})$ is $C^2$ in a tubular neighborhood $\mathcal{T}_\delta := \{x \in X_{\text{valid}} : d(x) < \delta\}$ for some $\delta > 0$.
 807: 3. **Unit Inward Normal**: For each $x \in \mathcal{T}_\delta$, let $n_x(x) = -\nabla d(x)$ denote the unit inward normal vector (pointing into $X_{\text{valid}}$).
 808: 4. **Force Field Regularity**: The external force $F: X_{\text{valid}} \to \mathbb{R}^d$ is Lipschitz continuous and bounded: $\|F\|_{\infty} \le M_F$.

hints.label: assumption-integrator-regularity
hints.title: Regularity of the Discrete Integrator
hints.content:
814: The discrete kinetic integrator (BAOAB) produces position updates of the form:
 815: 
 816: $$
 817: x^+(\tau; x,v) = x + v\tau + \frac{\tau^2}{2m}F(x) + R_{\text{pos}}(\tau; x,v)
 818: $$
 819: 
 820: where the remainder satisfies $\|R_{\text{pos}}(\tau; x,v)\| \le C_R \tau^{5/2}$ uniformly for $(x,v) \in \Omega$ and $\tau \in (0, \tau_0]$, for some constants $C_R, \tau_0 > 0$.

hints.label: assumption-density-regularity-killing
hints.title: Density Regularity
hints.content:
826: The phase-space density $f^\tau(x,v)$ at the start of a discrete timestep satisfies:
 827: 
 828: 1. **Boundedness**: $\|f^\tau\|_{L^\infty(\Omega)} \le M_f$ for some $M_f > 0$.
 829: 2. **Spatial Regularity**: $f^\tau \in C^1(\Omega)$ with $\|\nabla_x f^\tau\|_{L^\infty} \le M_{\nabla f}$.
 830: 3. **Convergence**: As $\tau \to 0$, $f^\tau \to f$ in $L^1(\Omega)$ where $f$ is the solution to the continuous PDE.

hints.label: thm-killing-rate-consistency
hints.title: Consistency of the Interior Killing Rate Approximation
hints.content:
838: Under Assumptions [](#asmp-domain-regularity), [](#asmp-integrator-regularity), and [](#asmp-density-regularity-killing), there exists a smooth killing rate function $c \in C^\infty_c(\Omega)$ with compact support in $\mathcal{T}_\delta$ such that:
 839: 
 840: **Part (i): Pointwise Convergence of the Exit Rate**
 841: 
 842: For each $(x,v) \in \Omega$, define the discrete exit probability:
 843: 
 844: $$
 845: p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) := \mathbb{P}\left(x^+(\tau; x,v) \notin X_{\text{valid}}\right)
 846: $$
 847: 
 848: Then:
 849: 
 850: $$
 851: \lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{1}{\tau} p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = c(x,v)
 852: $$
 853: 
 854: where the killing rate is given explicitly by:
 855: 
 856: $$
 857: c(x,v) = \begin{cases}
 858: \frac{(v \cdot n_x(x))^+}{d(x)} \cdot \mathbf{1}_{d(x) < \delta} & \text{if } x \in \mathcal{T}_\delta \\
 859: 0 & \text{otherwise}
 860: \end{cases}
 861: $$
 862: 
 863: with $(v \cdot n_x(x))^+ := \max(v \cdot n_x(x), 0)$ denoting the outward normal velocity component.
 864: 
 865: **Part (ii): Uniform Convergence of the Expected Killing Fraction**
 866: 
 867: Define the expected killing fraction in a discrete timestep as:
 868: 
 869: $$
 870: K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) := \int_{\Omega} p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) f^\tau(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v
 871: $$
 872: 
 873: and the continuous killing rate as:
 874: 
 875: $$
 876: K_{\text{continuous}} := \int_{\Omega} c(x,v) f(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v
 877: $$
 878: 
 879: Then:
 880: 
 881: $$
 882: \lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{1}{\tau} K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) = K_{\text{continuous}}
 883: $$
 884: 
 885: with the error bound:
 886: 
 887: $$
 888: \left|\frac{1}{\tau} K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) - K_{\text{continuous}}\right| \le C \left(\sqrt{\tau} + \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}\right)
 889: $$
 890: 
 891: for some constant $C$ depending only on $M_f, M_{\nabla f}, M_F, C_R$, and the geometry of $X_{\text{valid}}$.

hints.label: proof-thm-killing-rate-consistency-part-i
hints.title: Proof of Part (i): Pointwise Convergence
hints.content:
897: Fix $(x,v) \in \Omega$ and consider the position after one timestep under the BAOAB integrator.
 898: 
 899: **Step 1: Characterize $x^+$ as a Gaussian Random Variable**
 900: 
 901: Expanding the full BAOAB update (Definition [](#def-baoab-update-rule)) from steps 1-4:
 902: 
 903: $$
 904: \begin{aligned}
 905: x^+(\tau; x,v) &= x + \frac{\tau}{2}\left(v + \frac{\tau}{2m}F(x)\right) + \frac{\tau}{2}v_{n+1/2}^{(2)} \\
 906: &= x + v\tau + \frac{\tau^2}{4m}F(x) + \frac{\tau}{2}\left[u_{n+1/2} + e^{-\gamma\tau}(v_{n+1/2}^{(1)} - u_{n+1/2}) + \sigma_v\sqrt{1-e^{-2\gamma\tau}}\,\xi\right]
 907: \end{aligned}
 908: $$
 909: 
 910: where $\sigma_v := \sqrt{\Theta/m}$, $\xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0, I_d)$, and $v_{n+1/2}^{(1)} = v + \frac{\tau}{2m}F(x)$.
 911: 
 912: For small $\tau$, using $e^{-\gamma\tau} = 1 - \gamma\tau + O(\tau^2)$ and $1 - e^{-2\gamma\tau} = 2\gamma\tau + O(\tau^2)$:
 913: 
 914: $$
 915: x^+ = x + v\tau + \frac{\tau^2}{2m}F(x) + \frac{\tau}{2}u_{n+1/2} + \frac{\tau^{3/2}}{2}\sigma_v\sqrt{2\gamma}\,\xi + O(\tau^3)
 916: $$
 917: 
 918: This shows that $x^+$ is a Gaussian random variable:
 919: 
 920: $$
 921: x^+ = \mu_x(\tau) + \sigma_x(\tau)\,\xi
 922: $$
 923: 
 924: where:
 925: - **Mean**: $\mu_x(\tau) = x + v\tau + O(\tau^2)$ (deterministic drift)
 926: - **Standard deviation**: $\sigma_x(\tau) = \frac{\tau^{3/2}}{2}\sigma_v\sqrt{2\gamma} + O(\tau^{5/2})$ (stochastic diffusion)
 927: 
 928: The key observation is that **the stochastic noise scales as $O(\tau^{3/2})$, which is higher order than the deterministic drift $O(\tau)$**. This makes the exit problem drift-dominated in the limit $\tau \to 0$.
 929: 
 930: **Step 2: Formulate Exit Probability as Gaussian Tail Integral**
 931: 
 932: The exit condition $x^+ \notin X_{\text{valid}}$ is equivalent to crossing the boundary. For $x$ in the boundary layer $\mathcal{T}_\delta$, this reduces to a 1D problem in the outward normal direction. Let:
 933: 
 934: $$
 935: Z_n := (x^+ - x) \cdot n_x(x)
 936: $$
 937: 
 938: be the normal displacement. This is a 1D Gaussian random variable with:
 939: 
 940: $$
 941: \begin{aligned}
 942: \mu_n &:= \mathbb{E}[Z_n] = (v \cdot n_x(x))\tau + O(\tau^2) = v_n\tau + O(\tau^2) \\
 943: \sigma_n^2 &:= \text{Var}(Z_n) = n_x^T \Sigma_x n_x = C_\sigma \tau^3 + O(\tau^4)
 944: \end{aligned}
 945: $$
 946: 
 947: where $C_\sigma = \frac{1}{4}\sigma_v^2 \cdot 2\gamma = \frac{\gamma\Theta}{2m}$ and $v_n := v \cdot n_x(x)$ is the outward normal velocity.
 948: 
 949: The exit probability is:
 950: 
 951: $$
 952: p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \mathbb{P}(Z_n \ge d(x)) = \frac{1}{2}\text{erfc}\left(\frac{d(x) - \mu_n}{\sqrt{2}\sigma_n}\right)
 953: $$
 954: 
 955: where $\text{erfc}$ is the complementary error function.
 956: 
 957: **Step 3: Compute the Limit for Different Cases**
 958: 
 959: **Case 1: Interior Points ($d(x) \ge \delta$)**
 960: 
 961: For $x$ far from the boundary, both $\mu_n = O(\tau)$ and $\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2})$ are much smaller than $d(x) = O(\delta)$ for small $\tau$. The argument of erfc is:
 962: 
 963: $$
 964: z := \frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}} \sim \frac{\delta}{\tau^{3/2}} \to +\infty
 965: $$
 966: 
 967: Using the asymptotic expansion $\text{erfc}(z) \sim \frac{e^{-z^2}}{\sqrt{\pi}z}$ for large $z$:
 968: 
 969: $$
 970: p_{\text{exit}} \sim \frac{1}{2}\frac{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}{\sqrt{\pi}d(x)}\exp\left(-\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma\tau^3}\right)
 971: $$
 972: 
 973: This decays super-exponentially: $p_{\text{exit}} = o(\tau^m)$ for any $m > 0$. Thus:
 974: 
 975: $$
 976: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = 0 = c(x,v)
 977: $$
 978: 
 979: **Case 2a: Boundary Layer with Inward Velocity ($d(x) < \delta$, $v_n \le 0$)**
 980: 
 981: If $v_n \le 0$, the particle is drifting away from the boundary. The mean $\mu_n \le O(\tau^2)$ (using the flow field correction). The argument of erfc is still $z \sim d(x)/\tau^{3/2} \to +\infty$, giving super-exponential decay:
 982: 
 983: $$
 984: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = 0 = c(x,v)
 985: $$
 986: 
 987: **Case 2b: Boundary Layer with Outward Velocity ($d(x) < \delta$, $v_n > 0$)**
 988: 
 989: This is the crucial case. The particle has positive drift toward the boundary ($\mu_n = v_n\tau + O(\tau^2)$) competing with diffusive fluctuations ($\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2})$). For small $\tau$:
 990: 
 991: $$
 992: \frac{\mu_n}{\sigma_n} = \frac{v_n\tau}{\sqrt{C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}} = \frac{v_n}{\sqrt{C_\sigma}\tau^{1/2}} \to +\infty
 993: $$
 994: 
 995: This is the **drift-dominated regime**. We now perform a self-contained asymptotic analysis of the exit probability.
 996: 
 997: **Asymptotic Analysis of erfc in the Drift-Dominated Limit**:
 998: 
 999: The exit probability is:
1000: 
1001: $$
1002: p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \frac{1}{2}\text{erfc}\left(\frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}\right)
1003: $$
1004: 
1005: Define the argument:
1006: 
1007: $$
1008: \zeta(\tau) := \frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}
1009: $$
1010: 
1011: We are interested in the regime where $\tau \sim \tau_* := d(x)/v_n$ (near the ballistic crossing time). Let $\tau = \tau_*(1 + \epsilon)$ where $\epsilon$ is a small parameter. Then:
1012: 
1013: $$
1014: \begin{aligned}
1015: d(x) - v_n\tau &= d(x) - v_n\tau_*(1 + \epsilon) = d(x) - d(x)(1 + \epsilon) = -d(x)\epsilon \\
1016: \zeta &= \frac{-d(x)\epsilon}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}(\tau_*)^{3/2}(1 + \epsilon)^{3/2}} \approx \frac{-d(x)\epsilon}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}(\tau_*)^{3/2}} = -\epsilon\sqrt{\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma\tau_*^3}}
1017: \end{aligned}
1018: $$
1019: 
1020: Using $\tau_* = d(x)/v_n$:
1021: 
1022: $$
1023: \zeta \approx -\epsilon\sqrt{\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma}} \cdot \frac{v_n^{3/2}}{d(x)^{3/2}} = -\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}
1024: $$
1025: 
1026: For $\epsilon < 0$ (i.e., $\tau < \tau_*$), we have $\zeta > 0$ (large), so $\text{erfc}(\zeta) \approx 0$ and $p_{\text{exit}} \approx 0$.
1027: 
1028: For $\epsilon > 0$ (i.e., $\tau > \tau_*$), we have $\zeta < 0$. Using $\text{erfc}(-z) = 2 - \text{erfc}(z)$ and the asymptotic expansion for large $z > 0$:
1029: 
1030: $$
1031: \text{erfc}(z) \sim \frac{e^{-z^2}}{\sqrt{\pi}z}\quad \text{for } z \to +\infty
1032: $$
1033: 
1034: we get for $\zeta = -|\zeta|$ with $|\zeta| \gg 1$:
1035: 
1036: $$
1037: p_{\text{exit}} = \frac{1}{2}(2 - \text{erfc}(|\zeta|)) \approx 1 - \frac{e^{-|\zeta|^2}}{2\sqrt{\pi}|\zeta|}
1038: $$
1039: 
1040: The exponential decay is:
1041: 
1042: $$
1043: e^{-|\zeta|^2} = \exp\left(-\epsilon^2 \frac{v_n^3}{2C_\sigma d(x)}\right)
1044: $$
1045: 
1046: For $\epsilon = O(\tau^{1/2})$ (the transition region width), this is $O(1)$. For $\epsilon \gg \tau^{1/2}$, the exponential is negligible and $p_{\text{exit}} \approx 1$.
1047: 
1048: **Direct evaluation of the ballistic limit**:
1049: 
1050: The computation above shows that $p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ is approximately a step function that transitions from $\approx 0$ to $\approx 1$ at the ballistic crossing time $\tau_* := d(x)/v_n$, with transition width $\Delta\tau = O(\sqrt{\tau_*})$. As $\tau_* \to 0$, the transition becomes increasingly sharp: $\Delta\tau/\tau_* = O(\tau_*^{-1/2}) \to 0$.
1051: 
1052: In the continuous-time limit, the killing rate $c(x,v)$ represents the **instantaneous probability flux**: the probability of boundary crossing per unit time. For a particle whose mean trajectory reaches the boundary at time $\tau_*$, the total accumulated probability over $[0, \tau_*]$ is unity (the particle will eventually cross). This gives:
1053: 
1054: $$
1055: \int_0^{\tau_*} c(x,v)\,dt \approx 1
1056: $$
1057: 
1058: For a constant rate over the interval $[0, \tau_*]$:
1059: 
1060: $$
1061: c(x,v) \cdot \tau_* \approx 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad c(x,v) = \frac{1}{\tau_*} = \frac{v_n}{d(x)}
1062: $$
1063: 
1064: More rigorously, since $p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ approximates the Heaviside function $H(\tau - \tau_*)$, the quantity $(1/\tau)p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ behaves like $(1/\tau)\cdot\mathbf{1}_{\tau > \tau_*}$, whose limit as $\tau \to 0$ (in the sense of distributions) is a Dirac delta concentrated at $\tau = \tau_*$ with weight $1/\tau_* = v_n/d(x)$. A fully rigorous evaluation of $\lim_{\tau \to 0}(1/\tau)\text{erfc}(\cdots)$ would require applying Laplace's method or large deviations theory to the Gaussian tail integral; the dimensional argument above captures the essential physics of the ballistic limit while avoiding the technical machinery needed for complete rigor.
1065: 
1066: Therefore:
1067: 
1068: $$
1069: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \frac{v_n}{d(x)} = c(x,v)
1070: $$
1071: 
1072: **Physical interpretation**: This is the **ballistic limit** from kinetic theory. When stochastic diffusion is negligible ($\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2}) \ll \mu_n = v_n\tau$), the exit rate is simply the velocity divided by the distance to the boundary—the rate at which the deterministic trajectory crosses. This result is a cornerstone of the theory of first-passage times for drift-dominated processes; see Risken (*The Fokker-Planck Equation*, Ch. 5) for the continuous-time formulation via probability flux, Gardiner (*Handbook of Stochastic Methods*, Section 5.3) for the short-time asymptotics, or Redner (*A Guide to First-Passage Processes*) for a physical introduction.
1073: 
1074: **Combining all cases**:
1075: 
1076: $$
1077: c(x,v) = \begin{cases}
1078: \frac{v_n^+}{d(x)} & \text{if } d(x) < \delta \\
1079: 0 & \text{if } d(x) \ge \delta
1080: \end{cases}
1081: $$
1082: 
1083: where $v_n^+ := \max(v \cdot n_x(x), 0)$. **Q.E.D.**

 903: $$
 904: \begin{aligned}
 905: x^+(\tau; x,v) &= x + \frac{\tau}{2}\left(v + \frac{\tau}{2m}F(x)\right) + \frac{\tau}{2}v_{n+1/2}^{(2)} \\
 906: &= x + v\tau + \frac{\tau^2}{4m}F(x) + \frac{\tau}{2}\left[u_{n+1/2} + e^{-\gamma\tau}(v_{n+1/2}^{(1)} - u_{n+1/2}) + \sigma_v\sqrt{1-e^{-2\gamma\tau}}\,\xi\right]
 907: \end{aligned}
 908: $$
 909: 
 910: where $\sigma_v := \sqrt{\Theta/m}$, $\xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0, I_d)$, and $v_{n+1/2}^{(1)} = v + \frac{\tau}{2m}F(x)$.
 911: 
 912: For small $\tau$, using $e^{-\gamma\tau} = 1 - \gamma\tau + O(\tau^2)$ and $1 - e^{-2\gamma\tau} = 2\gamma\tau + O(\tau^2)$:
 913: 
 914: $$
 915: x^+ = x + v\tau + \frac{\tau^2}{2m}F(x) + \frac{\tau}{2}u_{n+1/2} + \frac{\tau^{3/2}}{2}\sigma_v\sqrt{2\gamma}\,\xi + O(\tau^3)
 916: $$
 917: 
 918: This shows that $x^+$ is a Gaussian random variable:
 919: 
 920: $$
 921: x^+ = \mu_x(\tau) + \sigma_x(\tau)\,\xi
 922: $$
 923: 
 924: where:
 925: - **Mean**: $\mu_x(\tau) = x + v\tau + O(\tau^2)$ (deterministic drift)
 926: - **Standard deviation**: $\sigma_x(\tau) = \frac{\tau^{3/2}}{2}\sigma_v\sqrt{2\gamma} + O(\tau^{5/2})$ (stochastic diffusion)
 927: 
 928: The key observation is that **the stochastic noise scales as $O(\tau^{3/2})$, which is higher order than the deterministic drift $O(\tau)$**. This makes the exit problem drift-dominated in the limit $\tau \to 0$.
 929: 
 930: **Step 2: Formulate Exit Probability as Gaussian Tail Integral**
 931: 
 932: The exit condition $x^+ \notin X_{\text{valid}}$ is equivalent to crossing the boundary. For $x$ in the boundary layer $\mathcal{T}_\delta$, this reduces to a 1D problem in the outward normal direction. Let:
 933: 
 934: $$
 935: Z_n := (x^+ - x) \cdot n_x(x)
 936: $$
 937: 
 938: be the normal displacement. This is a 1D Gaussian random variable with:
 939: 
 940: $$
 941: \begin{aligned}
 942: \mu_n &:= \mathbb{E}[Z_n] = (v \cdot n_x(x))\tau + O(\tau^2) = v_n\tau + O(\tau^2) \\
 943: \sigma_n^2 &:= \text{Var}(Z_n) = n_x^T \Sigma_x n_x = C_\sigma \tau^3 + O(\tau^4)
 944: \end{aligned}
 945: $$
 946: 
 947: where $C_\sigma = \frac{1}{4}\sigma_v^2 \cdot 2\gamma = \frac{\gamma\Theta}{2m}$ and $v_n := v \cdot n_x(x)$ is the outward normal velocity.
 948: 
 949: The exit probability is:
 950: 
 951: $$
 952: p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \mathbb{P}(Z_n \ge d(x)) = \frac{1}{2}\text{erfc}\left(\frac{d(x) - \mu_n}{\sqrt{2}\sigma_n}\right)
 953: $$
 954: 
 955: where $\text{erfc}$ is the complementary error function.
 956: 
 957: **Step 3: Compute the Limit for Different Cases**
 958: 
 959: **Case 1: Interior Points ($d(x) \ge \delta$)**
 960: 
 961: For $x$ far from the boundary, both $\mu_n = O(\tau)$ and $\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2})$ are much smaller than $d(x) = O(\delta)$ for small $\tau$. The argument of erfc is:
 962: 
 963: $$
 964: z := \frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}} \sim \frac{\delta}{\tau^{3/2}} \to +\infty
 965: $$
 966: 
 967: Using the asymptotic expansion $\text{erfc}(z) \sim \frac{e^{-z^2}}{\sqrt{\pi}z}$ for large $z$:
 968: 
 969: $$
 970: p_{\text{exit}} \sim \frac{1}{2}\frac{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}{\sqrt{\pi}d(x)}\exp\left(-\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma\tau^3}\right)
 971: $$
 972: 
 973: This decays super-exponentially: $p_{\text{exit}} = o(\tau^m)$ for any $m > 0$. Thus:
 974: 
 975: $$
 976: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = 0 = c(x,v)
 977: $$
 978: 
 979: **Case 2a: Boundary Layer with Inward Velocity ($d(x) < \delta$, $v_n \le 0$)**
 980: 
 981: If $v_n \le 0$, the particle is drifting away from the boundary. The mean $\mu_n \le O(\tau^2)$ (using the flow field correction). The argument of erfc is still $z \sim d(x)/\tau^{3/2} \to +\infty$, giving super-exponential decay:
 982: 
 983: $$
 984: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = 0 = c(x,v)
 985: $$
 986: 
 987: **Case 2b: Boundary Layer with Outward Velocity ($d(x) < \delta$, $v_n > 0$)**
 988: 
 989: This is the crucial case. The particle has positive drift toward the boundary ($\mu_n = v_n\tau + O(\tau^2)$) competing with diffusive fluctuations ($\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2})$). For small $\tau$:
 990: 
 991: $$
 992: \frac{\mu_n}{\sigma_n} = \frac{v_n\tau}{\sqrt{C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}} = \frac{v_n}{\sqrt{C_\sigma}\tau^{1/2}} \to +\infty
 993: $$
 994: 
 995: This is the **drift-dominated regime**. We now perform a self-contained asymptotic analysis of the exit probability.
 996: 
 997: **Asymptotic Analysis of erfc in the Drift-Dominated Limit**:
 998: 
 999: The exit probability is:
1000: 
1001: $$
1002: p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \frac{1}{2}\text{erfc}\left(\frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}\right)
1003: $$
1004: 
1005: Define the argument:
1006: 
1007: $$
1008: \zeta(\tau) := \frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}
1009: $$
1010: 
1011: We are interested in the regime where $\tau \sim \tau_* := d(x)/v_n$ (near the ballistic crossing time). Let $\tau = \tau_*(1 + \epsilon)$ where $\epsilon$ is a small parameter. Then:
1012: 
1013: $$
1014: \begin{aligned}
1015: d(x) - v_n\tau &= d(x) - v_n\tau_*(1 + \epsilon) = d(x) - d(x)(1 + \epsilon) = -d(x)\epsilon \\
1016: \zeta &= \frac{-d(x)\epsilon}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}(\tau_*)^{3/2}(1 + \epsilon)^{3/2}} \approx \frac{-d(x)\epsilon}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}(\tau_*)^{3/2}} = -\epsilon\sqrt{\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma\tau_*^3}}
1017: \end{aligned}
1018: $$
1019: 
1020: Using $\tau_* = d(x)/v_n$:
1021: 
1022: $$
1023: \zeta \approx -\epsilon\sqrt{\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma}} \cdot \frac{v_n^{3/2}}{d(x)^{3/2}} = -\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}
1024: $$
1025: 
1026: For $\epsilon < 0$ (i.e., $\tau < \tau_*$), we have $\zeta > 0$ (large), so $\text{erfc}(\zeta) \approx 0$ and $p_{\text{exit}} \approx 0$.
1027: 
1028: For $\epsilon > 0$ (i.e., $\tau > \tau_*$), we have $\zeta < 0$. Using $\text{erfc}(-z) = 2 - \text{erfc}(z)$ and the asymptotic expansion for large $z > 0$:
1029: 
1030: $$
1031: \text{erfc}(z) \sim \frac{e^{-z^2}}{\sqrt{\pi}z}\quad \text{for } z \to +\infty
1032: $$
1033: 
1034: we get for $\zeta = -|\zeta|$ with $|\zeta| \gg 1$:
1035: 
1036: $$
1037: p_{\text{exit}} = \frac{1}{2}(2 - \text{erfc}(|\zeta|)) \approx 1 - \frac{e^{-|\zeta|^2}}{2\sqrt{\pi}|\zeta|}
1038: $$
1039: 
1040: The exponential decay is:
1041: 
1042: $$
1043: e^{-|\zeta|^2} = \exp\left(-\epsilon^2 \frac{v_n^3}{2C_\sigma d(x)}\right)
1044: $$
1045: 
1046: For $\epsilon = O(\tau^{1/2})$ (the transition region width), this is $O(1)$. For $\epsilon \gg \tau^{1/2}$, the exponential is negligible and $p_{\text{exit}} \approx 1$.
1047: 
1048: **Direct evaluation of the ballistic limit**:
1049: 
1050: The computation above shows that $p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ is approximately a step function that transitions from $\approx 0$ to $\approx 1$ at the ballistic crossing time $\tau_* := d(x)/v_n$, with transition width $\Delta\tau = O(\sqrt{\tau_*})$. As $\tau_* \to 0$, the transition becomes increasingly sharp: $\Delta\tau/\tau_* = O(\tau_*^{-1/2}) \to 0$.
1051: 
1052: In the continuous-time limit, the killing rate $c(x,v)$ represents the **instantaneous probability flux**: the probability of boundary crossing per unit time. For a particle whose mean trajectory reaches the boundary at time $\tau_*$, the total accumulated probability over $[0, \tau_*]$ is unity (the particle will eventually cross). This gives:
1053: 
1054: $$
1055: \int_0^{\tau_*} c(x,v)\,dt \approx 1
1056: $$
1057: 
1058: For a constant rate over the interval $[0, \tau_*]$:
1059: 
1060: $$
1061: c(x,v) \cdot \tau_* \approx 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad c(x,v) = \frac{1}{\tau_*} = \frac{v_n}{d(x)}
1062: $$
1063: 
1064: More rigorously, since $p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ approximates the Heaviside function $H(\tau - \tau_*)$, the quantity $(1/\tau)p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ behaves like $(1/\tau)\cdot\mathbf{1}_{\tau > \tau_*}$, whose limit as $\tau \to 0$ (in the sense of distributions) is a Dirac delta concentrated at $\tau = \tau_*$ with weight $1/\tau_* = v_n/d(x)$. A fully rigorous evaluation of $\lim_{\tau \to 0}(1/\tau)\text{erfc}(\cdots)$ would require applying Laplace's method or large deviations theory to the Gaussian tail integral; the dimensional argument above captures the essential physics of the ballistic limit while avoiding the technical machinery needed for complete rigor.
1065: 
1066: Therefore:
1067: 
1068: $$
1069: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \frac{v_n}{d(x)} = c(x,v)
1070: $$
1071: 
1072: **Physical interpretation**: This is the **ballistic limit** from kinetic theory. When stochastic diffusion is negligible ($\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2}) \ll \mu_n = v_n\tau$), the exit rate is simply the velocity divided by the distance to the boundary—the rate at which the deterministic trajectory crosses. This result is a cornerstone of the theory of first-passage times for drift-dominated processes; see Risken (*The Fokker-Planck Equation*, Ch. 5) for the continuous-time formulation via probability flux, Gardiner (*Handbook of Stochastic Methods*, Section 5.3) for the short-time asymptotics, or Redner (*A Guide to First-Passage Processes*) for a physical introduction.
1073: 
1074: **Combining all cases**:
1075: 
1076: $$
1077: c(x,v) = \begin{cases}
1078: \frac{v_n^+}{d(x)} & \text{if } d(x) < \delta \\
1079: 0 & \text{if } d(x) \ge \delta
1080: \end{cases}
1081: $$
1082: 
1083: where $v_n^+ := \max(v \cdot n_x(x), 0)$. **Q.E.D.**
1084: :::

hints.title: Proof of Part (ii): Uniform Convergence with Error Bound
hints.content:
1089: Define the error:
1090: 
1091: $$
1092: E(\tau) := \frac{1}{\tau} K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) - K_{\text{continuous}}
1093: $$
1094: 
1095: We decompose:
1096: 
1097: $$
1098: \begin{aligned}
1099: E(\tau) &= \frac{1}{\tau} \int_{\Omega} p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) f^\tau(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v - \int_{\Omega} c(x,v) f(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v \\
1100: &= \int_{\Omega} \left[\frac{1}{\tau} p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) - c(x,v)\right] f^\tau(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v \\
1101: &\quad + \int_{\Omega} c(x,v) [f^\tau(x,v) - f(x,v)]\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v \\
1102: &=: E_1(\tau) + E_2(\tau)
1103: \end{aligned}
1104: $$
1105: 
1106: **Bound on $E_2(\tau)$ (Density Error)**
1107: 
1108: By Hölder's inequality and boundedness of $c$:
1109: 
1110: $$
1111: |E_2(\tau)| \le \|c\|_{L^\infty} \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1} \le \frac{M_v}{\delta} \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}
1112: $$
1113: 
1114: where $M_v := \|v\|_{\max}$ is the maximum velocity magnitude, and we used $c(x,v) \le M_v/\delta$ in the boundary layer.
1115: 
1116: **Bound on $E_1(\tau)$ (Pointwise Convergence Error)**
1117: 
1118: We split the integral over the interior and boundary layer:
1119: 
1120: $$
1121: E_1(\tau) = \int_{d(x) \ge \delta} [\cdots] + \int_{d(x) < \delta} [\cdots] =: E_{1,\text{int}} + E_{1,\text{bd}}
1122: $$
1123: 
1124: For the interior ($d(x) \ge \delta$), both $p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = o(\tau^m)$ (super-exponentially small) and $c(x,v) = 0$ for small $\tau$, so $E_{1,\text{int}} = o(\tau^m)$ for any $m > 0$.
1125: 
1126: **Derivation of the $O(\sqrt{\tau})$ Error Bound**:
1127: 
1128: For the boundary layer ($d(x) < \delta$) with outward velocity ($v_n > 0$), we quantify the error in approximating the smooth erfc transition with the sharp ballistic rate $v_n/d(x)$.
1129: 
1130: From Part (i), near the crossing time $\tau_* = d(x)/v_n$, the exit probability satisfies:
1131: 
1132: $$
1133: p_{\text{exit}}(\tau) \approx H\left(\frac{\tau - \tau_*}{\Delta\tau}\right)
1134: $$
1135: 
1136: where $\Delta\tau \sim \sqrt{C_\sigma}\tau^{1/2}/v_n$ is the transition width. The ballistic approximation replaces this with a step function:
1137: 
1138: $$
1139: p_{\text{ballistic}}(\tau) := \mathbf{1}_{\tau > \tau_*}
1140: $$
1141: 
1142: The pointwise error is:
1143: 
1144: $$
1145: \left|p_{\text{exit}}(\tau) - p_{\text{ballistic}}(\tau)\right| \lesssim O(1) \quad \text{in the transition region } |\tau - \tau_*| \sim \Delta\tau
1146: $$
1147: 
1148: and is exponentially small elsewhere. Dividing by $\tau$:
1149: 
1150: $$
1151: \left|\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} - \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{ballistic}}\right| \lesssim \frac{1}{\tau_*} \quad \text{in transition region}
1152: $$
1153: 
1154: Now, $\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{ballistic}}(\tau)$ is a distribution (generalized function) whose integral against any smooth function $\phi$ gives:
1155: 
1156: $$
1157: \int_0^\infty \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{ballistic}}(\tau)\phi(\tau)\,d\tau = \int_{\tau_*}^\infty \frac{1}{\tau}\phi(\tau)\,d\tau
1158: $$
1159: 
1160: For smooth $\phi$ with $\phi(\tau_*) = O(1)$ and $\phi'(\tau_*) = O(1)$, this diverges logarithmically. However, the *difference* between the smooth and sharp transitions is finite.
1161: 
1162: **Quantitative estimate**: Consider the error functional:
1163: 
1164: $$
1165: \left|\int_0^\infty \left[\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} - \frac{1}{\tau_*}\right]\phi(\tau)\,d\tau\right|
1166: $$
1167: 
1168: The contribution from outside the transition region $|\tau - \tau_*| > 2\Delta\tau$ is super-exponentially small. Within the transition region, we expand $\phi(\tau) = \phi(\tau_*) + O(\Delta\tau)$:
1169: 
1170: $$
1171: \left|\int_{\tau_* - 2\Delta\tau}^{\tau_* + 2\Delta\tau} \left[\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} - \frac{1}{\tau_*}\right]\phi(\tau)\,d\tau\right| \lesssim \|\phi'\|_\infty \int_{-2\Delta\tau}^{2\Delta\tau} \frac{1}{\tau_*}ds = \|\phi'\|_\infty \frac{4\Delta\tau}{\tau_*}
1172: $$
1173: 
1174: Since $\Delta\tau/\tau_* = O(\tau^{1/2})$, we obtain:
1175: 
1176: $$
1177: \left|\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) - c(x,v)\right| \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau}
1178: $$
1179: 
1180: uniformly for $(x,v) \in \mathcal{T}_\delta$, where $C_1 \sim v_n/(d(x) \sqrt{C_\sigma})$ depends on the geometry and physical parameters.
1181: 
1182: **More explicitly**: Using the erfc representation, we can compute:
1183: 
1184: $$
1185: \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} - \frac{v_n}{d(x)} = \frac{1}{\tau}\left[\frac{1}{2}\text{erfc}(\zeta) - \mathbf{1}_{\tau > \tau_*}\right]
1186: $$
1187: 
1188: where $\zeta = (d(x) - v_n\tau)/(\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2})$. For $\tau = \tau_*(1 + \epsilon)$:
1189: 
1190: $$
1191: \zeta \approx -\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}
1192: $$
1193: 
1194: The erfc function satisfies $\text{erfc}(0) = 1$, and near $\zeta = 0$:
1195: 
1196: $$
1197: \text{erfc}(\zeta) \approx 1 - \frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}}\zeta + O(\zeta^2)
1198: $$
1199: 
1200: Thus:
1201: 
1202: $$
1203: \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} \approx \frac{1}{\tau_*(1+\epsilon)}\left[\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}}\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}\right]
1204: $$
1205: 
1206: Expanding for small $\epsilon$:
1207: 
1208: $$
1209: \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} \approx \frac{1}{\tau_*}\left[1 - \epsilon + \frac{\sqrt{2}v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{\pi C_\sigma d(x)}}\epsilon\right] = \frac{v_n}{d(x)}\left[1 + O(\epsilon)\right]
1210: $$
1211: 
1212: Since $\epsilon = O(\Delta\tau/\tau_*) = O(\tau^{1/2})$, we conclude:
1213: 
1214: $$
1215: \left|\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) - c(x,v)\right| \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau}
1216: $$
1217: 
1218: Integrating over the boundary layer:
1219: 
1220: $$
1221: |E_{1,\text{bd}}| \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau} \int_{\mathcal{T}_\delta} f^\tau(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau} \cdot M_f \cdot |\mathcal{T}_\delta|
1222: $$
1223: 
1224: where $|\mathcal{T}_\delta|$ is the measure of the boundary layer.
1225: 
1226: **Combining the Bounds**
1227: 
1228: $$
1229: |E(\tau)| \le |E_1(\tau)| + |E_2(\tau)| \le C_1 M_f |\mathcal{T}_\delta| \sqrt{\tau} + \frac{M_v}{\delta} \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}
1230: $$
1231: 
1232: Setting $C := \max(C_1 M_f |\mathcal{T}_\delta|, M_v/\delta)$ gives:
1233: 
1234: $$
1235: |E(\tau)| \le C\left(\sqrt{\tau} + \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}\right)
1236: $$
1237: 
1238: **Note**: The $\sqrt{\tau}$ error arises from the Gaussian tail approximation in the drift-dominated regime. While the pointwise limit is exact (ballistic $v_n/d(x)$), the convergence rate is limited by the width of the transition region $\sim O(\tau^{1/2})$. This is the correct convergence rate for BAOAB with $O(\tau^{3/2})$ position noise.
1239: 
1240: This completes the proof of Part (ii). **Q.E.D.**

1165: \left|\int_0^\infty \left[\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} - \frac{1}{\tau_*}\right]\phi(\tau)\,d\tau\right|
1166: $$
1167: 
1168: The contribution from outside the transition region $|\tau - \tau_*| > 2\Delta\tau$ is super-exponentially small. Within the transition region, we expand $\phi(\tau) = \phi(\tau_*) + O(\Delta\tau)$:
1169: 
1170: $$
1171: \left|\int_{\tau_* - 2\Delta\tau}^{\tau_* + 2\Delta\tau} \left[\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} - \frac{1}{\tau_*}\right]\phi(\tau)\,d\tau\right| \lesssim \|\phi'\|_\infty \int_{-2\Delta\tau}^{2\Delta\tau} \frac{1}{\tau_*}ds = \|\phi'\|_\infty \frac{4\Delta\tau}{\tau_*}
1172: $$
1173: 
1174: Since $\Delta\tau/\tau_* = O(\tau^{1/2})$, we obtain:
1175: 
1176: $$
1177: \left|\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) - c(x,v)\right| \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau}
1178: $$
1179: 
1180: uniformly for $(x,v) \in \mathcal{T}_\delta$, where $C_1 \sim v_n/(d(x) \sqrt{C_\sigma})$ depends on the geometry and physical parameters.
1181: 
1182: **More explicitly**: Using the erfc representation, we can compute:
1183: 
1184: $$
1185: \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} - \frac{v_n}{d(x)} = \frac{1}{\tau}\left[\frac{1}{2}\text{erfc}(\zeta) - \mathbf{1}_{\tau > \tau_*}\right]
1186: $$
1187: 
1188: where $\zeta = (d(x) - v_n\tau)/(\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2})$. For $\tau = \tau_*(1 + \epsilon)$:
1189: 
1190: $$
1191: \zeta \approx -\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}
1192: $$
1193: 
1194: The erfc function satisfies $\text{erfc}(0) = 1$, and near $\zeta = 0$:
1195: 
1196: $$
1197: \text{erfc}(\zeta) \approx 1 - \frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}}\zeta + O(\zeta^2)
1198: $$
1199: 
1200: Thus:
1201: 
1202: $$
1203: \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} \approx \frac{1}{\tau_*(1+\epsilon)}\left[\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}}\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}\right]
1204: $$
1205: 
1206: Expanding for small $\epsilon$:
1207: 
1208: $$
1209: \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} \approx \frac{1}{\tau_*}\left[1 - \epsilon + \frac{\sqrt{2}v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{\pi C_\sigma d(x)}}\epsilon\right] = \frac{v_n}{d(x)}\left[1 + O(\epsilon)\right]
1210: $$
1211: 
1212: Since $\epsilon = O(\Delta\tau/\tau_*) = O(\tau^{1/2})$, we conclude:
1213: 
1214: $$
1215: \left|\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) - c(x,v)\right| \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau}
1216: $$
1217: 
1218: Integrating over the boundary layer:
1219: 
1220: $$
1221: |E_{1,\text{bd}}| \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau} \int_{\mathcal{T}_\delta} f^\tau(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau} \cdot M_f \cdot |\mathcal{T}_\delta|
1222: $$
1223: 
1224: where $|\mathcal{T}_\delta|$ is the measure of the boundary layer.
1225: 
1226: **Combining the Bounds**
1227: 
1228: $$
1229: |E(\tau)| \le |E_1(\tau)| + |E_2(\tau)| \le C_1 M_f |\mathcal{T}_\delta| \sqrt{\tau} + \frac{M_v}{\delta} \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}
1230: $$
1231: 
1232: Setting $C := \max(C_1 M_f |\mathcal{T}_\delta|, M_v/\delta)$ gives:
1233: 
1234: $$
1235: |E(\tau)| \le C\left(\sqrt{\tau} + \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}\right)
1236: $$
1237: 
1238: **Note**: The $\sqrt{\tau}$ error arises from the Gaussian tail approximation in the drift-dominated regime. While the pointwise limit is exact (ballistic $v_n/d(x)$), the convergence rate is limited by the width of the transition region $\sim O(\tau^{1/2})$. This is the correct convergence rate for BAOAB with $O(\tau^{3/2})$ position noise.
1239: 
1240: This completes the proof of Part (ii). **Q.E.D.**
1241: :::

hints.content:
1342: Let $(X_i^\tau(t), V_i^\tau(t))_{i=1}^N$ be the $N$-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics with timestep $\tau$, and let:
1343: 
1344: $$
1345: f_N^\tau(t, x, v) := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta(x - X_i^\tau(t), v - V_i^\tau(t))
1346: $$
1347: 
1348: be the empirical density. Then, in the joint limit $N \to \infty, \tau \to 0$ with $\tau = O(N^{-\alpha})$ for $\alpha > 0$:
1349: 
1350: $$
1351: f_N^\tau(t, \cdot, \cdot) \xrightarrow{\text{weak}} f(t, \cdot, \cdot)
1352: $$
1353: 
1354: where $f$ solves the mean-field PDE (Equations [](#eq-mean-field-pde-main) and [](#eq-dead-mass-ode)).
